articles.headline: Intel Lawsuit Questions Place of Hedge Funds in Retirement Plans
articles.snippet: A former employee sued the computing giant, saying that big bets on hedge funds and private equity increased costs and hurt participants in the plans.
articles.abstract: A former employee sued the computing giant, saying that big bets on hedge funds and private equity increased costs and hurt participants in the plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We push the boundaries.”

articles.headline: F.D.A. Takes Issue With the Term ‘Non-G.M.O.’
articles.snippet: The F.D.A.’s stance on labeling has not changed, but it has added some confusion to the mix for consumers and for those companies that are voluntarily including more information on their packaging.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A.’s stance on labeling has not changed, but it has added some confusion to the mix for consumers and for those companies that are voluntarily including more information on their packaging.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lost in the news about the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of genetically engineered salmon on Thursday was its long-awaited guidelines on labeling food with or without genetically altered plant ingredients.

articles.headline: Lego’s Success Leads to Competitors and Spinoffs
articles.snippet: Lego has made new products based on its interlocking bricks, and its creations have been featured in animated films. Its success has encouraged competition.
articles.abstract: Lego has made new products based on its interlocking bricks, and its creations have been featured in animated films. Its success has encouraged competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Paul Hollingsworth tried to recreate “Jurassic Park” in a video using Lego bricks, he ran into a roadblock. Lego offers plenty of T. rexes, velociraptors and other dinosaurs, but not Richard Attenborough or Jeff Goldblum, who played characters in the movie.

articles.headline: Paris and Mali Attacks Expose Lethal Qaeda-ISIS Rivalry
articles.snippet: The competition between the two groups, first provoked by differing strategies in Syria, will be hard to stamp out even if armies can weaken the jihadists in the Middle East and Africa.
articles.abstract: The competition between the two groups, first provoked by differing strategies in Syria, will be hard to stamp out even if armies can weaken the jihadists in the Middle East and Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Before the hostage crisis at a Malian hotel was over, before the gunmen had even been identified, admirers of Al Qaeda and the rival Islamic State started jostling on social media over which of the jihadist organizations was more righteous and more prominent.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Donald Trump Sets Off a Furor With Call to Register Muslims in the U.S.
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump drew back from his call for a mandatory registry of Muslims in the United States, capping a week where candidates discussed their approaches to terrorism.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump drew back from his call for a mandatory registry of Muslims in the United States, capping a week where candidates discussed their approaches to terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under assault from Democrats and Republicans alike, Donald J. Trump on Friday drew back from his call for a mandatory registry of Muslims in the United States, trying to quell one of the ugliest controversies yet in a presidential campaign like few others.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Unilever Finds That Shrinking Its Footprint Is a Giant Task
articles.snippet: Unilever has pledged to cut its environmental impact in half while improving the health of one billion people, but sustainability is turning out to be complicated.
articles.abstract: Unilever has pledged to cut its environmental impact in half while improving the health of one billion people, but sustainability is turning out to be complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hellmann’s mayonnaise is known for many things — making egg salad delicious, being loaded with fat, that old “bring out the best” jingle. To date, however, it hasn’t been associated with sustainability. Mayo is a processed food made by huge conglomerates, not a symbol of environmentalism.

articles.headline: ISIS Women and Enforcers in Syria Recount Collaboration, Anguish and Escape
articles.snippet: Three young women who fled to southern Turkey recalled their experiences as members of the Islamic State morality police in Raqqa, Syria.
articles.abstract: Three young women who fled to southern Turkey recalled their experiences as members of the Islamic State morality police in Raqqa, Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTHERN TURKEY — Dua had only been working for two months with the Khansaa Brigade, the all-female morality police of the Islamic State, when her friends were brought to the station to be whipped.

articles.headline: Pentagon Expands Inquiry Into Intelligence on ISIS Surge
articles.snippet: The Pentagon has seized a trove of emails and documents as it widens an investigation into Central Command over accusations that officials had overstated the progress of airstrikes against the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon has seized a trove of emails and documents as it widens an investigation into Central Command over accusations that officials had overstated the progress of airstrikes against the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Islamic State fighters overran a string of Iraqi cities last year, analysts at United States Central Command wrote classified assessments for military intelligence officials and policy makers that documented the humiliating retreat of the Iraqi Army. But before the assessments were final, former intelligence officials said, the analysts’ superiors made significant changes.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Mark Mazzetti and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Wall St. Ties Linger as Image Issue for Hillary Clinton
articles.snippet: At a time when liberals are ascendant in the party, some Democrats believe Hillary Rodham Clinton’s time representing Wall Street as a senator could become a vulnerability.
articles.abstract: At a time when liberals are ascendant in the party, some Democrats believe Hillary Rodham Clinton’s time representing Wall Street as a senator could become a vulnerability.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Wittneben simmered as he listened to Hillary Rodham Clinton defend her ties to Wall Street during last weekend’s Democratic debate. He lost 40 percent of his savings in individual retirement accounts during the Great Recession, while Mrs. Clinton has received millions of dollars from the kinds of executives he believes should be in jail.

articles.headline: Hotel Attack in Mali Reverses Gains in Fight Against Extremism
articles.snippet: The fatal attack on a hotel in Mali’s capital leads to questions about how a democratic society can protect itself from a few determined extremists.
articles.abstract: The fatal attack on a hotel in Mali’s capital leads to questions about how a democratic society can protect itself from a few determined extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — The terrorists chose carefully: There are nearly always French, Russian and even a few American visitors to be found in the hotel restaurant, around the pool, in the health club or on the thin black-leather sofas of the glass-fronted lobby, now shattered by gunfire.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey, Adam Nossiter, Carlotta Gall and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Massachusetts’s Rejection of Common Core Test Signals Shift in U.S.
articles.snippet: As states have rejected tests tied to the Common Core standards, no about-face has resonated more than that of Massachusetts, known as a leader in education reform.
articles.abstract: As states have rejected tests tied to the Common Core standards, no about-face has resonated more than that of Massachusetts, known as a leader in education reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It has been one of the most stubborn problems in education: With 50 states, 50 standards and 50 tests, how could anyone really know what American students were learning, or how well?

articles.headline: With Ben Carson, the Doctor and the Politician Can Vary Sharply
articles.snippet: As a surgeon, Dr. Carson was praised for his dedication and attention to detail, but as a candidate, he has sometimes seemed imprecise or ill informed.
articles.abstract: As a surgeon, Dr. Carson was praised for his dedication and attention to detail, but as a candidate, he has sometimes seemed imprecise or ill informed.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he was not in the operating room at Johns Hopkins Hospital, performing one of his 400 surgeries a year, Dr. Ben Carson could often be seen walking slowly through the hallways, hands behind his back, nodding, smiling and speaking softly to co-workers and students who approached.
articles.byline: By Pam Belluck and Steve Eder

articles.headline: For Auto Enthusiasts, the Right to Tinker With Cars’ Software
articles.snippet: Federal copyright law now allows drivers to beef up their vehicle’s performance without incurring the legal wrath of carmakers.
articles.abstract: Federal copyright law now allows drivers to beef up their vehicle’s performance without incurring the legal wrath of carmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Car owners in the United States can soon play Volkswagen engineer, courtesy of the federal government.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Pfizer and Allergan Reach $150 Billion Merger Deal
articles.snippet: The deal, to be announced Monday, would create a huge new pharmaceutical giant and could potentially help Pfizer lower its American tax rate.
articles.abstract: The deal, to be announced Monday, would create a huge new pharmaceutical giant and could potentially help Pfizer lower its American tax rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pfizer has clinched a blockbuster merger with a fellow drug maker, one worth more than $150 billion, that can best be described in superlatives.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Pearson’s Big Paydays Defy the Odds Against Print Media
articles.snippet: The sales of The Financial Times and The Economist for about $2 billion cumulatively raise questions about whether the deals will pay off financially for the buyers.
articles.abstract: The sales of The Financial Times and The Economist for about $2 billion cumulatively raise questions about whether the deals will pay off financially for the buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been tough sledding for print media. More than 150 newspapers have closed or converted to digital-only offerings in the last two years. Recently the magazine giants Condé Nast and Time Inc. have both cut employees and closed magazines.

articles.headline: Paris Attacks and Other Assaults Seen as Evidence of a Shift by ISIS
articles.snippet: Attacks carried out far from the Islamic State’s base in Iraq and Syria upend the view held by the United States and its allies that the group was a regional threat.
articles.abstract: Attacks carried out far from the Islamic State’s base in Iraq and Syria upend the view held by the United States and its allies that the group was a regional threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The recent attacks in Paris and Beirut and the downing of a Russian airliner in Egypt were the first results of a centrally planned terrorism campaign by a wing of the Islamic State leadership that oversees “external” targets, according to American and European intelligence officials.

articles.headline: The Ad Council Adapts to Stay Relevant in an Age of Social Action
articles.snippet: The longtime creator of public service announcements hopes its new eye emoji, which is part of the “I Am a Witness” campaign, will resonate with the public in a way that’s reminiscent of Smokey Bear.
articles.abstract: The longtime creator of public service announcements hopes its new eye emoji, which is part of the “I Am a Witness” campaign, will resonate with the public in a way that’s reminiscent of Smokey Bear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Could an eye emoji become as beloved — and recognizable — as Smokey Bear?

articles.headline: Start-Up Leaders Embrace Lobbying as Part of the Job
articles.snippet: Today’s tech companies have accepted lobbying as an essential part of doing business.
articles.abstract: Today’s tech companies have accepted lobbying as an essential part of doing business.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last year, the personal butler service Hello Alfred won a top prize in Silicon Valley created for promising new technology start-ups, putting the company on a path toward millions of dollars in investment.

articles.headline: Checkpoints Isolate Many Immigrants in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley
articles.snippet: The Border Patrol has traffic checkpoints up to 100 miles north of Mexico, confining undocumented immigrants to a small world and, in the extreme, blocking children from specialized medical care.
articles.abstract: The Border Patrol has traffic checkpoints up to 100 miles north of Mexico, confining undocumented immigrants to a small world and, in the extreme, blocking children from specialized medical care.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROWNSVILLE, Tex. — Elizabeth Lopez swam across the Rio Grande 19 years ago to come to America, where she began cleaning houses and raising three daughters in this city of swaying palm trees at the southern tip of Texas.

articles.headline: Creditors Signal Potential Support for Overhauling Puerto Rico Debt
articles.snippet: Puerto Rico proposed to exchange existing bonds for new debt that would be less burdensome, and influential creditors for the first time were receptive.
articles.abstract: Puerto Rico proposed to exchange existing bonds for new debt that would be less burdensome, and influential creditors for the first time were receptive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of Puerto Rico’s most influential creditors are for the first time signaling support for the broad outline of a government proposal to overhaul the island’s crushing debts.

articles.headline: A Chill Grips a Michigan Haven for Syrian Families
articles.snippet: A tide of anti-refugee sentiment has shaken the large Syrian community in the Detroit area and the “beautiful life” that one family says it has finally achieved.
articles.abstract: A tide of anti-refugee sentiment has shaken the large Syrian community in the Detroit area and the “beautiful life” that one family says it has finally achieved.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich. — In late 2011, as killings, kidnappings and sectarian strife crept across the battle-scarred city of Homs, Syria, the family of four made a sorrowful decision: to flee.

articles.headline: Pfizer Chief Defends Merger With Allergan as Good for U.S.
articles.snippet: The agreement would be the latest, and largest, aimed at helping an American company lower its taxes by reincorporating overseas, a tactic known as corporate inversion.
articles.abstract: The agreement would be the latest, and largest, aimed at helping an American company lower its taxes by reincorporating overseas, a tactic known as corporate inversion.
articles.lead_paragraph: In phone calls to Washington lawmakers and Obama administration officials, the chief executive of the largest drug maker in the nation had a surprising message: A deal that would allow the company to move its headquarters to Ireland was actually good for the United States.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced, David Gelles and Leslie Picker

articles.headline: For Third Day, Brussels Is Paralyzed by Terror Dragnet
articles.snippet: The city remained jittery after a number of false alarms involving hotels and even City Hall, which was closed on Monday.
articles.abstract: The city remained jittery after a number of false alarms involving hotels and even City Hall, which was closed on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — On what would normally have been a busy Monday, this city in the heart of Europe remained shut down for a third straight day. Everything was closed — the schools, museums, government offices, public transportation, markets, shops, everything.
